title: initscripts: incorrect rootfs unmount logic causes dirty FS at every boot

sentences.text: While building a system based on an "aufs" root, I noticed that all partitions, at start up, always require fsck when the union is used, even after clean shutdowns.
That script contains this logic to determine which mounted entries not to unmount:
This protects all mounts "up to the / ".
However, such sed pattern matches the root filesystem as "is mounted on path <slash> AND the mount device starts with <slash>".
If the root filesystem is mounted from a node such as "aufs", the root line does not match, and all mounts end up in PROTECTED_MOUNTS.
I suppose the additional "/" constraint is a hack used to prevent matching the initial "rootfs /" entry.
This unmounts all entries down to the "base" root which is not the kernel standard "rootfs".
If / is mounted multiple times, this unmounts all "stacked" entries as well.
In the "aufs" case I described above, this ensures the additional partitions are cleanly unmounted.
